Award.AwardTitle: Theorizing and Advancing Teachers' Responsive Decision Making in the Domain of Rational Numbers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project addresses the growing need for research to support teachers in developing expertise in responsive decision making in which teachers elicit and build on children's mathematical thinking in the midst of instruction. Specific objectives include characterizing grades 3-5 teachers' responsive decision making in the domain of rational numbers, investigating how professional development can support the development of this form of teaching expertise, and exploring the relationship between degree of teachers' responsive decision making and student learning. Theoretical and practical contributions of this project address the discrepancy in the field's capacity to produce research-based knowledge about children's thinking versus provide resources to take up and effectively use this knowledge. The primary organization is The University of Texas at Austin, and major partner organizations include the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, SRI International, and Teachers Development Group.

In this professional development design study, researchers engage approximately 100 teachers in up to three years of professional development designed to empower teachers to make instructional decisions guided by a research-based framework of children's thinking about rational numbers, with an emphasis on children's informal ideas of partitioning quantities and their understanding of the fundamental properties of operations and equality. Data sources include direct observation of workshops and teachers' classrooms as well as teachers' performance and reflection on a variety of assessments. On the basis of what is learned from these multiple data sources across 3 cohorts of teachers, researchers will iteratively build and refine a model of responsive decision making and identify critical features of the development of this expertise. Further, using approximately half the sample, researchers collect student data to test the conjecture that responsive decision making is related to increased opportunities for students to learn.

The findings, assessments, and professional development generated by this project will help the field respond to the critical challenge of how to support teachers to take up and effectively use knowledge of children's mathematical thinking in instruction. Anticipated intellectual products include a model of teachers' responsive decision making in the domain of rational numbers, identification of landmarks and obstacles in teachers' development of responsive decision making, and knowledge about the relationship between teachers' expertise in responsive decision making and student learning. Anticipated professional development products include a web-based tool to support teachers' self-guided collaborative inquiry and a well-specified, scalable professional development course for teachers with an immediate outlet for dissemination through the ongoing work of Teachers Development Group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Responsive Teaching in Elementary Mathematics (RTEM) was a research and professional development study focused on teachers’ responsiveness to children’s fraction thinking. By “responsiveness to children’s thinking,” we mean teachers’ capacity to center children’s thinking during instruction and to continually adjust decisions about what to pursue and how to pursue it, based on the substance of children’s ideas and the mathematical connections within those ideas. Benefits of this type of teaching have been documented for children and teachers in prior research, yet responsiveness to children’s thinking is not the norm in elementary-grades mathematics instruction. RTEM contributed insights and innovations that address the challenges of understanding and supporting the development of teachers’ responsiveness to children’s mathematical thinking, in the topic of fractions.

Our multi-institution research team—consisting of researchers and practitioners—worked together to engage 92 upper elementary grades teachers in up to three years (150 hours) of professional development designed to develop expertise in responsiveness to children’s fraction thinking. The professional development focused on research-based knowledge of children’s fraction thinking and instructional practices that centered children’s thinking. We then studied teachers’ expertise in responsiveness and its relationship to children’s achievement. In doing this work, we built on Cognitively Guided Instruction (CGI), a research and professional development project with a long, impactful history in mathematics education. We share five of our major outcomes:

1) Identification of a set of related instructional practices: We conceptualized teachers’ responsiveness to children’s mathematical thinking in terms of a set of three interrelated instructional practices. The instructional practices included: questioning to support and extend children’s mathematical thinking, noticing children’s mathematical thinking, and anticipating children’s mathematical thinking. We found empirical support for the set in that the three practices were positively correlated with each other. Taking inspiration from Smith and Stein’s well-known “5 Practices” that support the development of teachers’ expertise in whole-class discussions, we suggest that this set of three practices can be used to anchor the development of teachers’ expertise in responsiveness to children’s mathematical thinking.

2) Significant links between instruction and children’s achievement: We explored the link between teachers’ expertise in instructional practices and children’s understanding of fraction quantities and relationships. We found that more expertise in teachers’ questioning to support and extend children’s thinking was linked to children’s higher fraction achievement. We also found that expertise in noticing and anticipating children’s thinking was foundational for teachers’ expertise in questioning to support and extend children’s thinking.

3) Insights for supporting teacher learning in professional development that links to children’s achievement: Our professional development included up to three years of support, and we found that more years of professional development was linked to children’s higher fraction achievement. Our design of the professional development offered new insights for supporting teacher learning via activities that increase in complexity as teachers’ expertise grows. We also created new resources to support teacher learning, such as frameworks to enhance (a) teachers’ understanding of children’s thinking about unit fractions and (b) teachers’ expertise in questioning to connect equations and children’s thinking about fraction story problems.

4) Deeper understanding of how teachers decide how to respond:  In earlier work, we conceptualized teachers’ professional noticing of children’s mathematical thinking in terms of three component skills: attending to a child’s strategy details, interpreting the child’s understandings, and deciding how to respond based on the child’s understandings. In RTEM, we refined our understanding of the deciding-how-to-respond component skill in two ways. First, we identified a simple yet powerful way of framing how teachers approach their decision making by distinguishing when teachers focus inside or outside of the child’s strategy. Although both kinds of focus can be useful, starting with and emphasizing an inside focus conveys to the child that their thinking is respected. Second, we explored two distinct kinds of teacher decision making: (a) deciding on follow-up questions, and (b) deciding on new tasks. Teachers in our study tended to have greater skill in deciding on follow-up questions, perhaps reflecting the typically limited opportunities teachers have to strategically select and adapt tasks linked to children’s thinking.

5) Spotlight on attending to individual children’s thinking throughout classroom lessons: In our prior work, we focused on questioning in teachers’ one-on-one work with children solving story problems outside of classroom instruction. In RTEM, we expanded our focus to include patterns of questioning that still attended to individual children’s thinking but during classroom instruction. Specifically, we documented the existence of these questioning patterns throughout lessons, including in the circulation phase during which children solved story problems and in the whole-group discussion phase during which children shared their strategies.
